It was the spring of the Lewis Reil Rebellion that we came west.

We were to start very early in May.

My brothers who were already up here heard the Indians & half breeds were coming up by back & knew my younger brother when bringing a car of settlers off to be with trouble on the way.

They were afraid they might meet one of them decided to water & go down our coming to delay our meeting.

A distance of 30 miles on foot a distance of 50 miles on horseback when snow was found thrown after.

Reil-Neil was captured instead of a lone course in June instead of May.

Peter Peace.
It was the spring of the Lewis Reil Rebellion that we came here. We were to start back early in May.

My brothers who were already up here heard the Indians & half breeds were coming up by blockade & knew my young brother when bringing a car of settlers about. They were afraid of the might need of trouble but the way they were decided to send a telegraph to delay our coming till things were settled. A distance of 30 miles on part of where furious war breaking up. But Reil was captured soon after & we came in June instead of May.

Your Yrs.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Diet: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ) and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

( ) All questionnaires
( ) Pioneer health conditions
( ) Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
( ) Pioneer housing
( ) Pioneer education and churchwork
( ) Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

3. Date: January 16, 1895

9. What were your reasons for coming West?

My Parents, Brother & Sisters came here.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people's reading about it, newspapers & magazines, pamphlets of information, etc.)

From reading newspapers & magazines.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?
Two Brothers & 2 married sisters had came 2 years previously.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
With my parents

13. What means of transportation did you use?
By R.R. train

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement etc.)
On the night we arrived at Indian Head at 12 o'clock at night, my Brother had arranged for Livery man to meet us, take us to his home for the night, but he didn't know just where he would drive, so that evening went to a party at Fearless Plains, so has we did not know were to go. Camped on station floor, it was a heavy forest & I felt pretty cold, the stable man came with kerosene.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
Indian Head (this was our experience)

16. Where did you settle or take up land?
About 12 miles East of Fearless Plains, that is my Father & Brothers did, we have lived in that district ever since.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?
Farming
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

Two brothers & I married fairly hard

Come 2 years previously

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

With my parents

13. What means of transportation did you use?

By train

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement)

The night we arrived at Badham

We had our beloved wife & my brother had arranged for their mom to meet us. Take us to his place for the night but he didn't know what to do so we went to the train station.

We didn't have any heavy gear except for bedrolls, blankets, the stable gear came with Redhead.

This was our experience, the only work of roadhouses and farmers. We came from the west side of the prairies.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

Redhead

16. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How often you harvest?

Farming

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

One of my sons have been Cops Director & one a Bee keepers Honey producers Association Director. My Husband was school teacher years ago.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.).

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in names since the first name was given, date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

Our first P.O. was named Chilten by the owner of the farm near it was kept by the owner of the farm near it was kept in the memory of the locality because it came from England. Our school was called Chilten School. Our town is Lemberg. I believe it was named by an official who had something to do with laying out the town, who came from Lemberg Germany. Present Creek is first about 1/2 mile north of here. Present Hills about 5 miles.
